awd_titl_txt: Testing community ecology theory as a framework for predicting co-infection: host resource ratios and viral pathogens
awd_abstract_narration:
A vast array of microbes (microscopic organisms), such as fungi, bacteria, and viruses, live inside every animal and plant on Earth. These microbial communities influence the growth, reproduction, and death rates of their hosts. Not all microbes are detrimental; the effects of microbes span the full range from causing deadly disease to being essential for host health. Despite the importance of microbial diversity to host well-being, we have little ability to predict the diversity and composition of microbial communities within hosts. This project will address this knowledge gap by testing whether a mathematical model developed originally for plants and algae ('resource-ratio theory') can be used to understand what determines the diversity and composition of the microbes that inhabit plant hosts. The data from these experiments will be used to understand when the predictions of the resource-ratio model apply to microbial communities and how it can be modified to make better predictions. A deeper understanding of the controls on microbial diversity will lead to more accurate predictions about microbes within hosts, which may speed advances in medicine and agriculture.

The researchers will grow plants in conditions that vary in the supply of critical soil nutrients, and they will manipulate and measure the abundance and diversity of a group of plant viruses that cause one of the most widespread and devastating diseases of cereal crops worldwide (barley and cereal yellow dwarf viruses; B/CYDV's). Five B/CYD virus species will be used to test the resource-ratio model in a series of growth-chamber and field experiments. In each experiment, they will create a wide range of conditions experienced by the viruses by growing host plants under different resource (nitrogen and phosphorus) supply rates. The researchers will measure viral abundance (titer) within individuals, using quantitative Polymerase Chain Reaction (qPCR) for each virus grown alone and in mixture. They will use viral abundance measurements through time to estimate virus population growth rates. The resource-ratio model will be tested with lab experiments, in order to predict viral diversity in each host. The resource-ratio model will also be modified to include elements of the virus and host biology that could cause deviations from the classic theory, such as host defences against infection by microbes and microbial effects on host nutrient content. To test the relevance of this model to more complex natural communities, the researchers will collect data on B/CYDV titers in field experiments replicated at a local field site and in 30 grasslands spanning 5 continents.

por.por_cntn:
Most animal and plant hosts are infected by multiple pathogens of widely varying virulence, and interactions among these pathogens occur at spatial scales ranging from subcellular to biogeographic. Ecological theory and mathematical models are a key tool for advancing epidemiology and ecology. However, most disease ecology models have focused on the dynamics of single pathogens and hosts, and their focus on among host dynamics (e.g., infection and transmission) leaves an important knowledge gap about how within-host pathogen population dynamics influence disease spread and risk. This is even more pressing because pathogen interactions are shaped by environmental conditions, such as host nutrition. Experimentation provides unique insights that can fuel understanding and prediction under novel conditions, yet experimentation with nutrition and infection is impossible or unethical in many host-pathogen systems.

This grant allowed us to pair theoretical and empirical approaches using plants, viruses, and aphid vectors to develop multi-scale insights into the effects of host nutrition (elemental resource supply) on pathogen community diversity and composition. Some key results of our work have demonstrated that different, but highly related, virus species can respond very differently to a host?s nutritional environment (via e.g., replication, competition, or facilitation). This means that the nutrient environment shapes the within-host diversity of pathogens and the probability of transmission and spread through host populations. Our empirical and modeling work also demonstrated that host nutrition can also control vector demography, with elevated nutrients leading to increased vector reproduction and spread. The nutrient environment determines each pathogen species? ability to compete for nutrients within a host, and this is likely underlain by adaptation; a change in the nutrient environment causes a short-term reduction in the ability of a virus species to transmit to new hosts.

The results of this work have advanced understanding of disease community ecology by explicitly pairing within-host pathogen population dynamics (e.g., competition between virus species in a host individual) with more classical disease models that have primarily focused on among-host transmission and host population-level infection prevalence. This work also has led to a deeper integration of disease and community ecology through the questions we have asked and the modeling approaches we have developed. Taken together, we have demonstrated, through a tight combination of experimentation and model development, that disease spread depends on interactions at multiple scales between host, pathogen, and environment. By studying disease starting with theoretical concepts from community and ecosystem ecology and parameterizing new mathematical models with empirical data, we have quantified how strongly these host-pathogen-environment interactions are likely to vary along abiotic gradients, such as changing nutrition or elemental supply rates.
